title: Goggle this — AR makes a spectacle
text:
Masks may be the must-have face wear of the moment, but Augmented Reality glasses are being teased as the future this week.

Images from Apple announcing its World Wide Developer Conference in June have all featured characters wearing spectacles, prompting speculation that it may be ready to talk about its much-rumoured AR glasses in order to crank up the developer community to produce software. Apple analyst Ming-Chi Kuo predicted last month that it would release a “helmet type” headset with AR and VR capabilities next year, costing around $1,000. 

Niantic Labs of Pokémon Go! AR fame also had news of AR glasses this week, with CEO John Hanke tweeting a partial image of a branded product and citing “the progress we're making to enable new kinds of devices”.

The Information reported on Tuesday that Snap would announce a more advanced version of its Spectacles smart glasses at its annual developer conference in May. They would feature displays capable of augmented reality effects such as superimposing Snapchat's lenses — a virtual beard or rainbow, say — on the real world.

There are harder and harsher uses of AR coming soon. Microsoft has just won a contract worth as much as $21.9bn to provide the US army with at least 120,000 augmented reality headsets. Its “Integrated Visual Augmentation System” headsets will help soldiers train, home in on targets or be aware of nearby threats by overlaying contextual information on top of the real world, according to Wednesday's announcement.

The Internet of (Five) Things

1. UK military seeks cyber specialists
Back to fighting virtual enemies, and the UK armed forces have relaxed hiring rules to allow candidates from the private sector to go directly into senior military roles, in a drive to recruit more cyber specialists, Helen Warrell reports.

2. Deliveroo down again
Food delivery service Deliveroo's shares fell by a less alarming 2 per cent on Thursday, a day after they plunged 26 per cent on debut. We've looked at the chill it could bring to the IPO market in London and analysed what caused the opening day “car crash”.

3. Tech's role in Biden's $2tn infrastructure plan
The huge government spending on US infrastructure announced by the president on Wednesday will include $180bn for research and development in areas such as artificial intelligence and biotechnology, aimed at improving competitiveness with China. A further $300bn is to be devoted to manufacturing subsidies, including help for chipmakers.

4. Spac boom fuels strongest start for global M&A since 1980
Deals worth $1.3tn were agreed in the first three months of 2021, more than any first quarter since at least 1980 and topping the heady levels of the dotcom boom at the turn of the millennium, according to figures from Refinitiv.

5. Kazuo Ishiguro and Venki Ramakrishnan: imagining a new humanity
In case you missed it, two Nobel laureates had a fascinating conversation at the recent FT Weekend festival on the ethics of AI and gene-editing, and the battle over truth. Here's the transcript.

Tech tools — Nova's audio earrings

If you're looking for more tech to wear on your head, Jonathan Margolis has been exploring the tech-as-jewellery trend. One example is Nova Audio's gold-plated pearl earrings, which are also earphones. The freshwater pearl in each is drilled through to fit minuscule electronics — a tiny speaker, two microphones, an antenna, a Bluetooth chip and a battery.
